question: Summarize the following evidence in 2-3 sentences.

content.source_1: I’m chiming in just on availability because that’s been my entire saga with this cereal. In Greenville and Columbia, I went through Publix, Kroger, Walmart, even a tiny IGA off US‑25, and the shelf tag is still there but the spot is always empty. The only time I saw it in person was a random endcap in Mount Pleasant last year, and it vanished the week after. I finally set up an Amazon search alert and the moment it popped back in stock I added it to my cart, but outside of Amazon I haven’t been able to touch a box in the Carolinas for two solid years.
content.source_2: I only care about the delivery cadence because my household burns through a box fast. I set up Subscribe & Save at a four‑week interval, and for three months it hit like clockwork: delivered on Tuesday afternoons, usually by 3 p.m., with the next one showing “preparing for shipment” the Friday prior. Then in June, one cycle got pushed to six weeks with a “supplier delay” note, and a September order was straight canceled as “temporarily unavailable.” I had to switch to a three‑week cadence to stay ahead, and now I keep a spare box sealed in the pantry as a buffer. When it does ship, the tracking is accurate and the hand‑off at my building’s mailroom is smooth.
content.source_3: As a whole experience, this has felt like rediscovering something I grew up with, but filtered through modern logistics. The flavor is exactly what I remember from grade school breakfasts—corny and crisp right out of the bag—and the pieces hold up in milk long enough for a full bowl without turning limp. Amazon makes it possible to keep it around; I set the subscription for every four weeks because my husband plows through a box in about 25 days, and the timing lines up with our grocery cycle. Price fluctuates a bit month to month, and twice the box arrived with a corner dented, but the inner bag stayed sealed and the cereal tasted fine. Considering I haven’t seen it on a local shelf in Charlotte since 2023, the online option is basically how we keep it in the house.
content.source_4: Focusing strictly on packaging, the last three deliveries showed a pattern I can’t ignore. Two boxes arrived in a larger shipping carton with just a single air pillow, and both cereal boxes had creased tops and one inner liner had a pinhole so the flakes were slightly soft by the time I opened it. The third shipment came double‑boxed with tight paper fill, and that one was pristine. I started inspecting the seals as soon as I receive them, checking the inner liner for stress marks near the seams and the expiration stamp. When the bag looks stretched or the corners are crushed, I’ve been filing a quick photo in the return center and Amazon has credited me, but I’d prefer consistent packing so the cereal doesn’t lose its snap.
content.source_5: Zeroing in on taste alone: something about the recipe feels different than the boxes I remember from the early 2000s. The corn aroma is milder when you first open the bag, and the sweetness seems dialed down a notch—more grain‑forward, less sugary top note. The flakes also feel thinner, which changes the way they soak; I get a quicker softening around the edges compared to how they used to stay crunchy through the last spoonful. It’s not a dramatic overhaul, but it’s noticeable when you eat it side by side with an older memory, and I found myself adding sliced banana to bring back the balance I expect.
content.source_6: From my perspective, availability isn’t the hard part at all—I pick it up at the Safeway on York Road in Baltimore almost every other week, and they keep four facings stocked near the specialty cereals. Oddly, Amazon has shown “currently unavailable” for me twice this summer, so I stopped relying on the app and just swing by the store during my commute. When I was in Hilton Head for vacation, the local Bi‑Lo clerk told me they haven’t carried it in months, so I guess it depends on the region. For me, brick‑and‑mortar has been more dependable than the online listings.
